case_name: Mcleod Company Ltd. v. Its Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 514 of 1963 filed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 514 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Award dated August 21, 1962 of Fourth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIII-332 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment Award dated August 21, 1962, of the Fourth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIII-332 of 1961.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 29, 1963 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: November 29, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-

facts.text: Industrial dispute between appellant Mcleod Company Ltd. and respondents its workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The industrial dispute between the appellant, Mcleod Company Ltd., and the respondents, its workmen, which has given rise to the present appeal

facts.text: Respondents claimed cash allowance in lieu of tiffin arrangements made by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: centered round two items of claim made by the respondents. The respondents claimed that they should be given cash allowance in lieu of the tiffin arrangements at present made by the appellant,

facts.text: Respondents urged discontinuation of appellant's practice of re-employing retired persons.

anchor.surface_text: and they urged that the practice started by the appellant of re-employing retired persons should be discontinued.

facts.text: Tribunal granted cash allowance: clerical staff As. 8/- per day, subordinate staff As. 6/- per day on working days.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has granted the first claim and has directed that the clerical staff should be paid As. -/8/- per day and the subordinate staff As. -/6 - per day on all working days

facts.text: Tribunal ordered stop re-employment of retired workmen in clerks above C grade.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the second claim, the Tribunal has ordered that the appellant should stop the re-employment of retired workmen in the category of clerks above C grade.

facts.text: Total employees of appellant: about 453; 36 officers, 90 junior grade Assistants, 196 clerks, 131 subordinate staff.

anchor.surface_text: The total number of employees in the employment of the appellant is about 453. 36 of them are officers 90 are junior grade Assistants, while 196 are clerks and 131 belong to the subordinate staff.

facts.text: Disputes concern clerks and subordinate staff.

anchor.surface_text: It is in regard to the last two categories of the appellants employees that the two items of dispute have reference in the present proceedings.

facts.text: In 1956 there was an industrial dispute between parties, tiffin claim not pressed, left to appellant's discretion.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1956 there was an industrial dispute between the parties, one of the items in dispute being the claim made by the respondents in respect of tiffin on working days. In those proceedings, however, the said claim was number pressed

facts.text: After 1956 award, parties entered direct negotiations on tiffin allowance; management assured to consider quantum.

anchor.surface_text: After the award was published, the parties entered into direct negotiations in respect of the claim of tiffin allowance and according to the evidence of Mr. Mazumdar, the General Secreatry of the respondents Union, the management then assured the respondents that it would companysider the quantum and value of free tiffin afterwards

facts.text: Settlement reached: clerical staff get two cups of tea and two biscuits, subordinate staff one cup of tea and one biscuit; on Saturdays same for both.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, two cups of tea and two biscuits are given by the appellant to the clerical staff, whilst one cup of tea and one biscuit is given to the members of the subordinate staff. On Saturdays the same ration of tiffin is supplied to the clerks and the sub-staff alike.

facts.text: Respondents contended tiffin arrangements unsatisfactory, urged cash allowance.

anchor.surface_text: In the present dispute, the respondents companytended that the tiffin arrangements made by the appellant were unsatisfactory and they urged that a cash allowance should be given to them in that behalf.

facts.text: Appellant has canteen under Factories Act, no obligation for cash tiffin allowance.

anchor.surface_text: Under the relevant provisions of the Factories Act, a canteen had been started by the appellant, but there is numberobligation on the appellant, either statutory or otherwise, for providing any further facility to the employees by way of giving them a cash allowance for tiffin.

facts.text: Dearness allowance paid according to Bengal Chamber of Commerce Formula.

anchor.surface_text: the dearness allowance is paid to the respondents according to the Bengal Chamber of Commerce Formula the said formula takes care substantially of the rise in the companyt of living from time to time.

facts.text: 31 comparable concerns supply free tiffin to employees (Ext. 10).

anchor.surface_text: the evidence shows that in the region as many as 31 companyparable companycerns are supplying free tiffin to their employees  Ext. 10 .

facts.text: Appellant has been making provision for tiffin throughout.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, as we have already seen, the appellant has throughout been making provision for tiffin of its employees

facts.text: 6 persons have been re-employed after retirement.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that as many as 6 persons have been re-employed

facts.text: In 1960, respondents raised dispute on re-employment, State Government refused reference as only 4 cases noticed.

anchor.surface_text: When the respondents had raised a dispute on this point in 1960, the State Government had refused to make a reference on the ground that only 4 cases of reemployment had been brought to its numberice,

facts.text: Chandi Charan Banerjee before retirement drew basic salary Rs. 380 plus dearness allowance; on re-employment got consolidated Rs. 250 without DA.

anchor.surface_text: Take, for instance, the case of Chandi Charan Banerjee. Before he retired, he was drawing a basic salary of Rs. 380 and dearness allowance. On his re-employment, he got a companysolidated salary of Rs. 250 without any dearness allowance.

facts.text: Re-employed persons paid much smaller salary for same work than before retirement.

anchor.surface_text: and that means that the re-appointed employee was getting about half his former wages for doing the same work .

facts.text: Re-employment of seniors hampers promotion prospects of juniors.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, if senior persons are re-employed after retirement, that is apt to retard or hamper the prospects of promotion to which the junior employees are entitled to look forward.

facts.text: Some re-employments actuated by humanitarian motives.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri companytends that in acceding partially to the demand made by the respondents, the Tribunal has overlooked the fact that the re-employment of retired persons was mainly inspired by humanitarian companysiderations.

facts.text: Re-employed persons made affidavit supporting appellant's practice.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the re-employed persons have made an affidavit supporting the practice adopted by the appellant can have numbermaterial bearing
Appeal by special leave from the judgment Award dated August 21, 1962, of the Fourth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIII-332 of 1961.

Under the relevant provisions of the Factories Act, a canteen had been started by the appellant, but there is no obligation on the appellant, either statutory or otherwise, for providing any further facility to the employees by way of giving them a cash allowance for tiffin.

concepts.interpretation: No statutory or other obligation to provide cash allowance for tiffin beyond canteen provisions.

concepts.interpretation: Arises from history of negotiations, settlements, and prevailing practices in comparable concerns, creating entitlement to tiffin amenity.

issues.text: Whether the respondents should be given cash allowance in lieu of the tiffin arrangements at present made by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The respondents claimed that they should be given cash allowance in lieu of the tiffin arrangements at present made by the appellant

issues.text: Whether the practice started by the appellant of re-employing retired persons should be discontinued

anchor.surface_text: and they urged that the practice started by the appellant of re-employing retired persons should be discontinued.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal's decision that the appellant was under an obligation to provide cash allowance for tiffin is erroneous in law warranting interference

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances, if the Tribunal took the view that the appellant was under an obligation to provide some cash allowance for tiffin to its employees, we do not see how we can interfere with it on the ground that the impugned decision is erroneous in law.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal's partial direction to stop re-employment of retired workmen in the category of clerks above C grade is improper or unjustified

anchor.surface_text: and that clearly cannot be permitted under industrial law. ... Thus considered, we see no justification for Mr. Sastris grievance that the limited direction issued by the award is either improper or unjustified.

arguments.claim: Re-employment of retired persons mainly inspired by humanitarian considerations and Tribunal overlooked this.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri contends that in acceding partially to the demand made by the respondents, the Tribunal has overlooked the fact that the re-employment of retired persons was mainly inspired by humanitarian considerations.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: uitable provision in that behalf That is how the prevailing arrangements for tiffin came to be introduced. Under these circumstances, if the Tribunal

arguments.court_reasoning: Some actuated by humanitarian motives conceded, but other factors like underpayment and promotion blockage override.

arguments.claim: Appellant under obligation to provide cash allowance for tiffin as implied condition of service based on history and comparable concerns.

anchor.surface_text: The history of the relations between the parties coupled with the prevailing practice in the comparable concerns in the region strongly supports the view taken by the Tribunal that in the appellants concern it was an implied condition of service that in addition to the wages and dearness allowance, a provision for tiffin was an amenity to which the employees were entitled.

arguments.claim: Re-employment introduces inferior wage structure to established award-based structure, impermissible under industrial law.

anchor.surface_text: Take, for instance, the case of Chandi Charan Banerjee. Before he retired, he was drawing a basic salary of Rs. 380 and dearness allowance. On his re-employment, he got a consolidated salary of Rs. 250 without any dearness allowance. and that means that the re-appointed employee was getting about half his former wages for doing the same work . This aspect of the matter introduces a serious infirmity in the, appellants case [...] and that clearly cannot be permitted under industrial law.

arguments.claim: Re-employment of seniors hampers promotion prospects of junior employees.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, if senior persons are re-employed after retirement, that is apt to retard or hamper the prospects of promotion to which the junior employees are entitled to look forward.

arguments.claim: Affidavits by re-employed persons supporting the practice have no material bearing.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the re-employed persons have made an affidavit supporting the practice adopted by the appellant can have no material bearing

arguments.court_reasoning: Re-employed persons bound to support appellant by nature of things.

holdings.text: if the Tribunal took the view that the appellant was under an obligation to provide some cash allowance for tiffin to its employees, we do not see how we can interfere with it on the ground that the impugned decision is erroneous in law.

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances, if the Tribunal took the view that the appellant was under an obligation to provide some cash allowance for tiffin to its employees, we do not see how we can interfere with it on the ground that the impugned decision is erroneous in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: History of parties' relations, post-award negotiations, assurances to consider tiffin value, and provision made thereafter, plus practice in 31 comparable concerns, justify tribunal's view of obligation.

holdings.text: in the appellants concern it was an implied condition of service that in addition to the wages and dearness allowance, a provision for tiffin was an amenity to which the employees were entitled.

anchor.surface_text: The history of the relations between the parties coupled with the prevailing practice in the comparable concerns in the region strongly supports the view taken by the Tribunal that in the appellants concern it was an implied condition of service that in addition to the wages and dearness allowance, a provision for tiffin was an amenity to which the employees were entitled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strongly supported by history of relations between parties and prevailing practice in comparable concerns in the region.

holdings.text: we do not think that the appellants grievance against the direction in the award that As. -/8/- and As. -/6/ - per day should be paid respectively to the members of the clerical staff and the substaff on all working days, can be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, we do not think that the appellants grievance against the direction in the award that As. -/8/- and As. -/6/ - per day should be paid respectively to the members of the clerical staff and the substaff on all working days, can be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from existence of implied condition of service for tiffin amenity.

holdings.text: If re-employments are made on the basis of reduced salary, that really means that the appellant is introducing a wage structure in respect of the reemployed personnel which is definitely inferior to the wage structure devised for the employees of the appellant by the award , and that clearly cannot be permitted under industrial law.

anchor.surface_text: and that means that the re-appointed employee was getting about half his former wages for doing the same work . This aspect of the matter introduces a serious infirmity in the, appellants case as it was presented before us by Mr. Sastri. If re-employments are made on the basis of reduced salary, that really means that the appellant is introducing a wage structure in respect of the reemployed personnel which is definitely inferior to the wage structure devised for the employees of the appellant by the award , and that clearly cannot be permitted under industrial law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Re-employment at substantially reduced pay (e.g., Rs. 250 consolidated vs prior Rs. 380 basic + DA for same work) undercuts award-devised wage structure.

holdings.text: Thus considered, we see no justification for Mr. Sastris grievance that the limited direction issued by the award is either improper or unjustified.

anchor.surface_text: It is in the light of these facts that the question posed by the respondents demand must be considered. Thus considered, we see no justification for Mr. Sastris grievance that the limited direction issued by the award is either improper or unjustified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited to clerks above C grade; justified by inferior wage issue, prior assurances disregarded, and impact on junior promotions, outweighing humanitarian motives in some cases.

holdings.text: The fact that the re-employed persons have made an affidavit supporting the practice adopted by the appellant can have no material bearing

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the re-employed persons have made an affidavit supporting the practice adopted by the appellant can have no material bearing in dealing with the point in the very nature of things, the said re-employed persons are bound to support the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Re-employed persons naturally bound to support employer.

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances, if the Tribunal took the view that the appellant was under an obligation to provide some cash allowance for tiffin to its employees, we do number see how we can interfere with it on the ground that the impugned decision is erroneous in law.

outcome.relief_summary: Tribunal's award upheld in full; cash tiffin allowance of As. 8/- per day to clerical staff and As. 6/- per day to subordinate staff granted; re-employment of retired clerks above C grade prohibited.

anchor.surface_text: and that means that the re-appointed employee was getting about half his former wages for doing the same work . This aspect of the matter introduces a serious infirmity in the, appellants case as it was presented before us by Mr. Sastri. If re-employments are made on the basis of reduced salary, that really means that the appellant is introducing a wage structure in respect of the reemployed personnel which is definitely inferior to the wage structure devised for the employees of the appellant by the award , and that clearly cannot be permitted under industrial law.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 addresses issue i4 by providing reasoning that re-employment at lower pay violates wage structure, justifying the tribunal's partial direction.

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances, if the Tribunal took the view that the appellant was under an obligation to provide some cash allowance for tiffin to its employees, we do number see how we can interfere with it on the ground that the impugned decision is erroneous in law.
adopted by the appellant in re-employing the retired personnel was number

edges.explanation: Holding h5 directly addresses and resolves issue i4 by finding no justification for grievance against the tribunal's limited direction.

anchor.surface_text: It is in the light of these facts that the question posed by the respondents demand must be considered. Thus considered, we see no justification for Mr. Sastris grievance that the limited direction issued by the award is either improper or unjustified.

Under these circumstances, if the Tribunal took the view that the appellant was under an obligation to provide some cash allowance for tiffin to its employees, we do number see how we can interfere with it on the ground that the impugned decision is erroneous in law.

edges.explanation: Issue of tiffin cash allowance is addressed by holding on implied service condition.
